cmd.cites.cmd.second.line.cite: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information § 2:2

prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Legal Bases Used by the Courts for the Protection of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: Property has been defined as:

That which is peculiar or proper to any person; that which belongs exclusively to one. In the strict legal sense, an aggregate of rights which are guaranteed and protected by the government … More specifically, ownership; the unrestricted and exclusive right to a thing; the right to dispose of a thing in every legal way, to possess it, to use it, and to exclude every one else from interfering with it.[1]

The word “property” refers to tangible property and “choses in action”. The definition of “choses in action” includes all property, tangible and intangible “whose terms of enjoyment could and would be measured according to the wording of the Letters Patent, or the Act of Legislature or other document that created it”.[2]

The property theory focuses on the nature of the information to be protected. It assumes that, even if others are not aware of the content of the information, they know of its existence. Thus, where a property right is recognized, the personal obligation as between two parties may give rise to an equitable interest in the property in relation to which the duty arises. Proponents of the property theory point to the fact that trade secrets and confidential business information are generally considered to be intellectual property and are, like other species of intellectual property, subject to property rights. Furthermore, confidential business information is frequently licensed or assigned, and is created through the same types of processes utilized in patent and copyright law.[3]
Many of the early cases used property law as the basis for determining liability for breach of confidential business information. In Millar v. Taylor,[4] Mr. Justice Yates held that:

Ideas are free. But while the author confines them to his study, they are like birds in a cage, which none but he can have a right to let fly: for, till he thinks proper to emancipate them, they are under his own dominion.

An author's unpublished manuscript therefore “is, in every sense, his peculiar property; and no man can take it from him, or make any use of it which he has not authorized, without being guilty of a violation of his property”.[5]
In Abernethy v. Hutchinson,[6] the court held that “the case could be viewed two ways—either as a question of trust, or a question of property”.
In the later decision of Boardman v. Phipps,[7] Lord Hodson, as part of the majority, held:

We are aware that what is called “know-how” in the commercial sense is property which may be very valuable as an asset. I agree with the learned judge and with the Court of Appeal that the confidential information acquired in this case which was capable of being and was turned to account can be properly regarded as the property of the trust.
Lord Guest, also part of the majority decision, confirmed that: “I see no reason why information and knowledge cannot be trust property”.[8]

In the Australian case, Deta Nominees Pty. Ltd. v. Viscount Plastic Products Ltd.,[9] the court took the property theory one step further. In that case, the court held that equity will be invoked in situations where information is the property of a person, into which category most, if not all, trade secret cases will fall. This seems to suggest that the origin of the equitable right is the fact that in most, if not all, cases of confidential information, there is a property right to be protected.

The issue of the legal basis for protection of confidential business information was discussed by the Supreme Court of Canada in the context of criminal law. In R. v. Stewart,[10] Lamer J., for the court, held that confidential information:

… possesses many of the characteristics of other forms of property: for example, a trade secret, which is a particular kind of confidential information, can be sold, licensed or bequeathed, it can be the subject of a trust or passed to a trustee in bankruptcy … The cases demonstrate that English and Canadian civil law protect confidential information. However, the legal basis for doing so has not been clearly established by the courts. Some cases have treated confidential information as property, and thus have entitled the owner to exclude others from the use thereof … On the other hand, the courts have recognized certain rights with respect to confidential information in the guise of an equitable obligation of good faith …

It appears that the protection afforded to confidential information in most civil cases arises more from an obligation of good faith or a fiduciary relationship than from a proprietary interest. No Canadian court has so far conclusively decided that confidential information is property, with all the civil consequences that such a finding would entail.
However, the possibility of confidential information being considered a proprietary right in civil cases is left open, as Lamer J. went on to say:

It is possible that, with time, confidential information will come to be considered as property in the civil law or even be granted special legal protection by statutory enactment. Even if confidential information were to be considered as property under civil law, it does not, however, automatically follow that it qualifies as property for the purposes of criminal law.[11]

There has as yet been no definitive word from the Supreme Court of Canada regarding the express acceptance or rejection of the property theory as the doctrinal basis for protection of confidential business information in civil cases. However, see Cadbury Schweppes Inc. v. FBI Foods Ltd.,[12] where the Supreme Court of Canada, while not closing the door on the issue, reaffirmed its reluctance to treat confidential information as a species of property.

In the United States, some American courts have specifically recognized a property right in an idea which is compensable in damages. In Belt v. Hamilton National Bank,[13] the plaintiff conceived of an idea for a radio program and asked the bank to be a sponsor. The plaintiff sought compensation in return for the sponsorship. The bank engaged the plaintiff but later cancelled the agreement and abandoned the program. Some time later, the bank took up the program with another individual. The plaintiff sued the bank for the value of his idea. The District Court held:

The law has recognized a qualified property right in trade secrets and grants injunctive relief against their use or disclosure by a breach of contract or a violation of confidence. It is but one step further to extend to ideas at least a limited property right … The law now gives effect to a property right in an idea even though the idea may be neither patentable nor subject to copyright.[14]
On appeal, the Circuit Court of Appeal, confirming the District Court judgment, held that:

… the dangers [of attributing common property to individual ownership] are sufficiently avoided to warrant the law in placing an idea among protected property rights when it is definite and concrete, new and novel, has usefulness and is disclosed for commercial purposes in circumstances which the parties ought reasonably to construe as contemplating compensation for its use.[15]

The finding of the Court of Appeal in the Belt v. Hamilton National Bank case was applied in Puente v. President and Fellows of Harvard College[16] and Ed Graham Productions, Inc. v. National Broadcasting Co.[17]

The American courts have stressed that, in order to be eligible for protection by the courts, an idea must be “original, concrete, useful and disclosed in circumstances which, reasonably construed, clearly indicate that compensation is contemplated if it is accepted and used”.[18] The purpose of this test is to ensure that the idea merits protection and would not exist but for the efforts of the author:

The law shies away from according protection to vagueness, and must do so especially in the realm of ideas with the obvious dangers of a contrary rule. An abstract idea, in any event when not the subject of a contract, is so unattached as to be deemed legally without the quality of individual identity or property.[19]
In addition, the idea must have been used without authorization. If there was independent knowledge of the general idea, and the idea was developed independently, there will be no liability.[20]

In the United States, the courts have begun using the misappropriation doctrine to grant remedies where the property rights in an idea have been infringed. The misappropriation doctrine has been defined to consist of the following three elements:
The plaintiff has made a substantial investment of time, effort and money such that a property right has been created.
The defendant has appropriated the thing at little or no cost, such that the defendant has “reaped where he has not sown”.
The plaintiff has been injured as a result of the defendant's actions.[21]

Similarly, in the British case of Saltman Engineering, Lord Greene said that “what makes [information] confidential is the fact that the maker of the document has used his brain and thus produced a result which can only be produced by somebody who goes through the same process”.[22]
In these cases, the basis of the right is clearly the nature of the information itself. However, a number of criticisms of the property theory have also been expressed.
Black's Law Dictionary, 6th ed. (St. Paul, Minn.: West Publishing Co., 1990), p. 1216; F.S. Cohen, “Dialogue on Private Property” (1954), 9 Rutgers L. Rev. 357 at p. 378.
